Procedure:
Internal Consumption:Basale leaves can be consumed raw in salads or cooked in various dishes such as soups, curries, and stir-fries.

They are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, making them a nutritious addition to the diet.In Ayurveda, Basale leaves are believed to have cooling properties, making them beneficial for balancing Pitta dosha and soothing conditions related to excess heat in the body.

Consuming Basale leaves regularly is believed to support digestion, improve appetite, and promote overall well-being.

Decoction or Juice:Fresh Basale leaves can be used to prepare a decoction or juice by boiling them in water and then straining the liquid.This decoction or juice can be consumed as a beverage for its potential medicinal properties, including promoting detoxification, reducing inflammation, and boosting immunity.It may be especially beneficial for individuals with digestive issues or inflammatory conditions.

External Use:Basale leaves can also be used externally for skincare purposes. A paste made from crushed Basale leaves can be applied topically to soothe skin irritations, reduce inflammation, and promote wound healing.The leaves may also be used in herbal baths or poultices for their cooling and rejuvenating effects on the skin.

Holistic Approach:In Ayurveda, Basale leaves are considered to be part of a holistic approach to health and wellness. They are valued not only for their nutritional content but also for their therapeutic properties in supporting overall vitality and balance in the body.
